div1.p: Circular

The administration in communicating to Messrs the merchants and retail dealers the enclosed decree has thought proper to take advantage of the opportunity to inform them that according to the declaration which they have to make concerning their trade within the delay prescribed by the article 2 of the decree of November 16th last, that is to say, until the 20 of December next, it will proceed commencing with the latter date to prepare the list of names indicating the description of business of each and the assesment of the corresponding contribution.

Gaboon December 8th 1866
The
Director of the Interior
(Signed) Goby

Approved

(Signe) Aube
Parle Commandant Superieur. Le Commandant Particulier ffous. de Juge de Paix (Signe) Aube
L'Ordosmateur ffous de tineteur de l'Interieur (Signe) Goby
We Rear-Admiral Commandant Superior of the Settlements of the Gold Coast and of Gaboon.

Whereas it appears by the Ministerial Despatch of January 15th 1866 that the Government of the Emperor is desirous of relieving the mother country of those Colonial expenses which are of a purely local character.
Whereas in our Circular dated September 21st that we informed Messrs the traders of the creation of annual protests and licence dues to commence on January 1st 1867.

Considering that the local trade has not yet contributed anything to the public changes of our settlements and that the Execution of the Colony finds itself necessitated to modify the state of things.
Upon the proposition of the Commandant Particular officiating as justice of the Peace and of the Ordonnateur acting as Director of the Interior.
Have decreed and do decree,
The annual licence dues at Gaboon are fixed at 600 francs.
Art 2nd Under the heads of Merchants are comprised all those whose principal business consists in receiving merchandise direct from abroad and in expecting the produce of the Colony.

Art. 3d Under the head of Retail dealers are comprised all those who receiving from abroad only the small portions of their goods, purchase the remainder from merchants and consignees reselling afterwards, partly by some whole sale, partly by retail without exporting native produce.
Art 4th On subject to licence dues, publicans, eating housekeepers, billiard-room keepers and grog-shops and all others selling liquor by retail in their establishments.

The payment of licence dues will
exempt from taking out a patent for any other business or profession carried on simultaneously and subject to patent dues.

Art 5th Masters and Supercargoes selling their cargoes on ship-board or ashore by wholesale or by retail will be subject to take out a patent, the amount of which shall be determined according to the value of the goods which the manifest shall attribute to them the proprietorship of consignment.
The dues for this patent will be payable for each distinct voyage whatever may be the duration of the stay in the Colony. They are fixed as follows;
Art 6th Below one thousand francs the goods will be considered as a simple private venture belonging to the Master or Supercargo, who in this case will have no patent dues to pay.

Any person in charge of a cargo who shall sell in stores other merchandise than those of which he has made the
declaration to the Executive, shall be punished by a fine fixed at the rate of the annual patent dues, levied on the description of business in which he is classed.
The patent dues accruing to the Treasury by virtue of the present article will be fixed by the Executive on sight of the manifest.

Art 7th With the exception specified by the proceeding article 4 in that which concerns the licences, no one will need to take out more than one patent, whatever may be the different branches of business in which he is engaged, but the patent dues will be payable on the most important class of business carried on.
Never-the-less a single patent can only cover the establishments hold, upon the same premises and under the same firm or by the same person.
The merchants patent will only cover one retail store in the of his establishment
Partners undoubtedly forming the same and sole house of business or trade, have only need of one patent for the firm.
The classification of persons subject to patents and licences according to the 2, 3, & 4 articles hereuntofore mentioned will be settled up between the 20th and 25th of December of each year.
Art 8th The list of those holding patents and licences will be prepared by the Ordonnateur and submitted to the Commandant Superior to be rendered executory.
The collection of the dues shall be made by the Treasurer in the usual manner and at the periods hereinafter appointed
Art 9th The patents and licences shall be taken out in the two first months of each half year; for the entire half year, but cannot be granted for a part of the half year.
The dues for patents and licences shall be paid.
For the first half year before the 15th of Febr'y
For the second half year before the 15th of Aug

Those who may undertake a profession a trade or an occupation in the course of a half year, which is subject to a patent or a licence will only be liable to pay the dues for the quarter but not for a less period than a quarter.
They must pay their proposition in the month of their starting in business. No patent or licence will be granted or renewed except upon the production beforehand of the receipt for the dues.
Art 10th Those persons holding patents or licences who have not paid their dues at the time herein before mentioned will receive from the Treasurer a notice free of cost.
Ten days after the notice then in arrear will receive an extract of the list rendered rendered excesitory by the Commandant Superior with order to pay.

In default of so doing within the period of three days the and goods of the defaulter will be seized
and sold to the amount of patent or licence dues, and of the expenses to which the proceedings may have given rise.

Art 11th No person will allowed to follow a profession or occupation subject to patent or licence dues without having first made a declaration at the office of the Executives, and undertaken to pay the regulation tax.
The traders subject to licence dues must also enter into an engagement to conform to the police rules, and to the hours of closing their establishments.
A certificate of these declarations and engagements will be delivered, which will be exchanged later for the patent or licence as the case may be.

Art 12th Any trader who is unable to produce his patent or licence to the Agents of the Executive or in lieu of it the proof that he inscribed on the list of those holding patents and licences or the certificate required by the proceeding article, will be
punished by a fine of 25 to 100 frs. without prejudice to the payment of the patent or licence dues which he may have depended, which dues he shall be compelled to pay for the entire year even if he should give notice of giving up his business.
Any person who may carry on a trade superior to that for which he has taken a patent will be made to pay the difference and a fine equal to that difference.

Any person subject to patent or licence dues who may discontinue his trade or occupation, is found to make his declaration thereof to the Executive beforehand provided always that the payment of dues for the half year cannot be dispensed with.

He will receive a certificate of his declaration So long as this formality has not been complied with the trader will be considered as continuing his business next
subject to pay the tax.
Art 13th All complaints relating to patents or licences dues must be addressed to the Ordonnateur who will give his opinion thereon to the party entrusted.
If the party persists in his complaint, the matter shall be refered to us with all the documents in support thereof to be decided by us.

Art 14th The Commandant Particulier acting as Justice of the Peace and the Ordonnateur acting as Director of the Interior are entrusted each in that which concerns him with the execution of the present decree which shall be published and registered wherever necessary.
Gabon December 8th 1866.
